nodes.bodyText: Should be able to just put @CacheEvict(...) on AddressBookService.update() instead of this manual invocation.

Will this break if someone renames the parameter?
If so use p1

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                        "#encodedFileId", unless = "#result == null")
          
          
            
                        "{#p1}", unless = "#result == null")
This was refactored to work on the service layer which changed with the key params, but good point.
Unless there's a reason otherwise
This was removed since the annotation can just be used, but you are correct that this should have been done.
Add a test for the cache eviction scenario if possible
Perhaps this test needs to be renamed to cacheAndEvictAddressBook, it does do an update/eviction and confirms that it was removed from the cache.

What happens if an error occurs before addressBookRepository.save() is called?
Would the last valid address book be evicted from the cache?

Also what about when addressBookRepository.save() is called in parse() then an error occurs after?
Should we be evicting the new valid address book?

After refactoring, the evict cache is called at the resolution of the method via an annotation.  That being said, it will not execute if an exception is thrown, I'm trying to evaluate if that is the best way to go or if it needs to switch back to something that fires regardless.
At 5mins it's probably not a big deal, though if your research shows otherwise you can add it in a follow up PR.
I think we're caching at the wrong layer here. We should not cache the repository but the service layer as caching here can cause problems with AddressBookServiceImpl.updatePreviousAddressBook().
@Cacheable should be here.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -90,7 +102,6 @@ public void update(FileData fileData) {
     public AddressBook getCurrent() {

nodes.bodyText:
I believe it was a mistake for us to have this catch here.
The result is an error parsing a valid address book would be caught and we wouldn't retry the whole file.
Can you remove this catch all together.
There shouldn't be any fallout in this minor refactor but let me know if you hit a snag as you address comments that makes it a bigger ask
Removed, all seems well with the tests

I'm hesitant to use a never expiring cache for such an important object. If we have a bug it will never self correct. We use the never expire cache only for entity IDs as they're insert only and not updateable like an address book. Even 30m might be too long and we can get away with much shorter without impacting performance. I think the cacheManager5m might be more appropriate.
That logic makes sense, I've knocked it down to the 5m manager.

Since we're effectively evicting all entries in the cache (one 102 file), we can just do the following and avoid the reflection penalty of using Spel expressions:
@CacheEvict(allEntries = true)

nodes.bodyText: Since there's current and historical and 101 and 102 address books, we should name this to indicate it's only storing the current 102 address book. e.g.  something likecurrent_102_address_book

I've removed the cacheNames and cacheManager, letting it use the default key gen is causing issues with my unit test to retrieve it, I'm looking into how to fix that.
